articles.headline: All-in-One PCs Look Good and Cost Plenty
articles.snippet: Three sleek and shiny PCs from Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Vizio offer the latest components but no DVD drives.
articles.abstract: Three sleek and shiny PCs from Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Vizio offer the latest components but no DVD drives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Try this simple test at home: What’s the name of Dell’s best-selling PC? Anybody? Anybody?

articles.headline: Report Bolsters the Case for Large U.S. Natural Gas Exports
articles.snippet: An Energy Department study concluded that the national economic benefits of significant natural gas exports far outweighed the potential for higher consumer energy prices.
articles.abstract: An Energy Department study concluded that the national economic benefits of significant natural gas exports far outweighed the potential for higher consumer energy prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In a finding that could help create a new industry of natural gas exports in the United States, a government study released on Wednesday concluded that the national economic benefits of significant natural gas exports far outweighed the potential for higher energy prices for consumers and industrial users of the fuel.

articles.headline: U.S.-Approved Arms for Libya Rebels Fell Into Jihadis’ Hands
articles.snippet: The Obama administration secretly gave its blessing to arms shipments to Libyan rebels from Qatar, but American officials grew alarmed at evidence that Qatar was turning some of the weapons over to militants.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration secretly gave its blessing to arms shipments to Libyan rebels from Qatar, but American officials grew alarmed at evidence that Qatar was turning some of the weapons over to militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration secretly gave its blessing to arms shipments to Libyan rebels from Qatar last year, but American officials later grew alarmed as evidence grew that Qatar was turning some of the weapons over to Islamic militants, according to United States officials and foreign diplomats.
articles.byline: By James Risen, Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: For PC Virus Victims, Pay or Else
articles.snippet: Ransomware — when a virus freezes a user’s computer and criminals demand money to unlock it — has become a lucrative online scheme.
articles.abstract: Ransomware — when a virus freezes a user’s computer and criminals demand money to unlock it — has become a lucrative online scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Kidnappers used to make ransom notes with letters cut out of magazines. Now, notes simply pop up on your computer screen, except the hostage is your PC.

articles.headline: In Fine Print of Fiscal Debate, Charities Unite to Defend Deductions
articles.snippet: Growing support for eliminating some of the tax breaks that high-income households get for charitable giving has some nonprofit groups worried.
articles.abstract: Growing support for eliminating some of the tax breaks that high-income households get for charitable giving has some nonprofit groups worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Proposals to cap or otherwise limit deductions in order to raise tax revenue from the wealthy are gaining bipartisan support in Washington — and making charities and nonprofits very worried.

articles.headline: Trail to a Hedge Fund, From a Cluster of Cases
articles.snippet: Federal investigators have charged many former employees of SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen, with trading on insider information.
articles.abstract: Federal investigators have charged many former employees of SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen, with trading on insider information.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April 2009, an F.B.I. agent visited the Silicon Valley home of Richard Choo-Beng Lee, a hedge fund manager with deep contacts inside technology companies. The government, the agent said, had overwhelming proof that Mr. Lee had engaged in insider trading. Within weeks, Mr. Lee confessed and began cooperating.

articles.headline: Boehner Gains Strong Backing From House Republicans
articles.snippet: The embrace from a broad swath of the rank-and-file may empower Speaker John A. Boehner as he negotiates on tax increases and spending cuts.
articles.abstract: The embrace from a broad swath of the rank-and-file may empower Speaker John A. Boehner as he negotiates on tax increases and spending cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a daunting fiscal crisis looming and conservatives outside the House torching him at every turn, Speaker John A. Boehner might be assumed to have a shaky hold on his gavel. Instead, it appears he is enjoying the broadest support of his tumultuous two-year speakership from House Republicans.

articles.headline: John McAfee, Software Pioneer, Is Arrested in Guatemala
articles.snippet: Mr. McAfee slipped over the border from his home in Belize, where police want to question him in a neighbor’s death.
articles.abstract: Mr. McAfee slipped over the border from his home in Belize, where police want to question him in a neighbor’s death.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The antivirus software pioneer John McAfee was arrested in Guatemala City on Wednesday after he slipped over the border from his home in Belize where police want to question him in their investigation of the murder of his neighbor.

articles.headline: Morsi Defends Wide Authority as Turmoil Rises in Egypt
articles.snippet: President Mohamed Morsi vowed to proceed with a vote on an Islamist-backed constitution that has set off deadly battles between his supporters and opponents.
articles.abstract: President Mohamed Morsi vowed to proceed with a vote on an Islamist-backed constitution that has set off deadly battles between his supporters and opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt descended deeper into political turmoil on Thursday as the embattled president, Mohamed Morsi, blamed an outbreak of violence on a “fifth column” and vowed to proceed with a referendum on an Islamist-backed constitution that has prompted deadly street battles between his supporters and their opponents.

articles.headline: In Shift of Jobs, Apple Will Make Some Macs in U.S.
articles.snippet: Some analysts are hopeful that the move by a big, innovative company like Apple could inspire a broader renaissance in American manufacturing, but a number of experts remain skeptical.
articles.abstract: Some analysts are hopeful that the move by a big, innovative company like Apple could inspire a broader renaissance in American manufacturing, but a number of experts remain skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple plans to join a small but growing number of companies that are bringing some manufacturing jobs back to the United States, drawn by the growing economic and political advantages of producing in their home market.
articles.byline: By Catherine Rampell and Nick Wingfield
